cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28
R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.

S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.

div.head:
WHERE TO WINTER IN EGYPT.
The Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Telephone No. 5 Helouan.
Tel. Address "Tewfik, Helouan."
If you seek Health, Rest, and Recreation, Do not Fail to Visit Helouan.
"The Tewfik is Helouan and Helouan is the Tewfik."
The Tewfik-Helouan,"should be known to all who purpose to visit Egypt. – Glasgow Herald.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"is surrounded by pure dessert air under the best possible conditions." – Lancet.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"enjoys an exceptional position." Egyptian Gazette.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"views from the windows absolutely charming – Egyptian Gazette.
Tel Address:
"Tewfik, Helouan."
Office in Cairo – Stephenson & Co.,(English Chermists), Opera Square, Telephone 82.

(late of Thos. Cook & Son).

div.head: CAIRO MENA HOUSE HOTEL
div.p: FIRST CLASS FAMILY HOTEL.
MODERATE TERMS.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head: CAIRO-SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: Is Now Open.

div.head:
PAGNON'S HOTELS,
LUXOR.
div.p: LUXOR HOTEL.–This old established hotel, accommodating 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident Doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Light, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court.
KARNAK HOTEL.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

div.head: Hotel Du Nil, Cairo.
div.p: The Most Quiet and Comfortable First Class Hotel.
Highest situation. Excellent Cuisine. Restaurant à la Carte at all time. Recherché Lunch and Dinner served on the Open Air Verandahs and beautiful gardens of the Hotel.
Afternoon Tea. Visitors to the Bazaars should lunch here.
Charges Moderate.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: "AL HAYAT" Helouan
div.p: First Class Health Resort
Unrivalled Position on the Mokattam Hills
96 metres above the level of the Nile, surrounded by desert.
All rooms full south with sheltered verandahs
Public Sitting Rooms in separate Pavilions communicating by glass corridors.
Electric Light–Steam-Heating–Lift.
Bathing, Air and Diet Cures. Resident Medical Director. All kinds of sports. Own stables. Omnibus meets all Trains.
Ilustrated Prospectus sent free on appplication

div.head: Borwick's Baking Powder.
div.p: Economical & Reliable.
60 Years' Reputation.
For Home-made Bread, Cakes, Pastry, Scones, Flour Puddings, Meat Pies, &c., &c.
It is Packed in Tins or Bottles, and will keep for years in perfect condition.
Supplied by Store-keepers and Grocers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Manufactory--1, Bunhill Row, London.
Wholesale Agents: Crosse & Blackwell Ltd., London ; C. & E. Morton, London; Walker & Meimarachi, Ltd., Cairo; J. B. Caffari, Alexandria.

div.head: LES BÉBÉS DÉPÉRISSENT TOUT COMME LES FLEURS!
div.p: Lorsque vous voyez vos enfants dépérir, se faner comme les fleurs dans la terre desséchée, il est grand temps, croyez-le, d'avoir recours a l'EMULSION SCOTT qui s'est si souvent montrée la sève revivifiante de ces tendres fleurs que sont les bébés.
L'Emulsion Scott
fait promptement et radicalement disparaître
ROUGEOLE, CROUP, BRONCHITE, COQUELUCHE, RACHITISME, ACCIDENTS DE DENTITION, FAIBLESSE OU DÉPÉRISSEMENT.
L'Emulsion Scott active 1'appétit et redonne au visage apâli de roses et fraiches couleurs; l'estomac le plus faible la supporte aisement, le palais le plus délicat laccepte avec plaisir.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.

div.head: MERRYWEATHERS' "UNIVERSAL" HAND-POWER PUMP.

For Fire Protection, Watering Plantations, Emptying Ponds, Draining Land, Pumping Liquid Manurs, General Pumping Purposes, & c.
Strongly made and nothing to get out of order.

TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
PORT ARTHUR
JAPANESE SUCCESS.
DESTRUCTION IN HARBOUR.
RUSSIAN SHIPS SUNK.
· JAPS WAITING OUTSIDE.
TOKIO, December 7. Another 5 hours armistice was agreed upon yesterday at Port Arthur, as the Russians desired to remove their dead.
The battleship Poltava has been sunk. The battleship Retoisan is listing badly, and the cruiser Bayan is stranded. The Japanese have occupied Akasaba Hill.
(Reuter.)
CHi-Fu, December 7. Subsequent to the occupation of Akasaba bill, the Japanese captured two other hills near It-shan.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, December 7. The Japanese bombardment at Port Arthur hassunk the "Poltava and damaged the Retvisan.
(Havas.)

Chr-Fu, December 8. The Japanese bombardment of the harbor was continued yesterday. Many shots took effect. The Peresviet was ignited. The Retvisan has been apparently sunk, and the Pobieda is listing to starboard.
(Reuter.)
Tokyo, December 8. The Japanese continue to bombard Port Arthur, aiming at the battleships Pallada, Peresviet, and Pobieda.
(Havas.)

Chi-Fu, December 8. The Peresviet has sunk and is submerged. The Ketvisan is nearly submerged. The PoHieda's stern is submerged. The Pallada is slightly sinking astern. The Sevastopol also appears to be sinking. The Bayan is on fire.
A steamer reports that she saw a strong Japanese squadron outside Port Arthur. It is believed that the entire fleet is there now.
(Reuter.) 1
SCENE ON 203-METRE HILL.

LONDON, December 8. Reuter's correspondent before Port Arthur, who visited the 203-metre hill at the close of a week's struggle, says the scene was awful. The crest of the bill was torn away and the trenches semi-obliterated. In a single section of 100 yards of trenches there were 200 Russian dead and wounded, horribly mangled by dynamite and grenades.
(Reuter.)
MANCHURIA.
ACTIVITY OF CHUN-CHUSES
TREMENDOUS CANNONADING.

St. PETERSBURG, December 7. The Russian correspondents at Mukden constantly refer to the activity of the Chunchuses, who are now well organized under the famous leader Tulisan. They are specially troublesome in their attempts to blow up bridges and the railway.
(Reuter.)

MUKDEN, December 7. A tremendous cannonading with siege guns began yesterday morning round Putiloff bill and the railway. The number of guns is constantly increasing. It is supposed that important developments will follow. (Reuter.)
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
RECEIVED BY THE POPE.
ROME, December 7. - The Duke of Connaught has been received ju audience by the Pope.
(Reuter.)
TRAGIC DEATH OF M. SYVETON.
ASPHYXIATED IN HIS ROOM.
Paris, December 8, 31. Syveton has died, having been asphyxiate ed through an escape of gas in his study,
(Havas.)
PARIS, December 9. M. Syveton, the aggressor of General André, "has been found dead, asphyxiated by gas in his study,
(Reuters)
THE BALTIC FLEET.
COALING OF VESSELS.
DEPARTURE FROM TANGIER.

PERIM, December 7. The yacht Catarina, from Djibouti, contradicts the dhows' report to the effect that the Russians had coaled at Musha. All the ships coaled at Djibouti from their own colliers, and also reprovisioned there.
(Reuter.)
TANGIER, December 7. The rest of Admiral Botrovosky's squadron, consisting of the cruiser Dnieper (ex Petersburg), two destroyers, and a transport, have left, travelling eastwards.
(Reuter.)
BREST, December 8. The destroyer Pronzitelni, mentioned on the 29th November, was repaired, and has since left.
(Reuter.)
COAL FOR THE BALTIC FLEET.
LONDON, December 8. The German collier Bengalia sailed from Cardiff for Batavia with 12,000 tons of coal, which it is believed is for the Baltic Fleet.
(Reuter.)
THIRD RUSSIAN SQUADRON.
LONDON, December 8. The Daily Mail learns from St. Petersburg that the Tsar yesterday decreed the despatch of a third squadron, which will not be composed of Black Sea vessels.
(Reuter.)
GENERAL NEWS.
ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION.
ADOPTED BY SENATE.
Paris, December 7. The Senate has adopted the Anglo-French Convention by 215 votes to 37. (Reuter.)

PARIS, December 7. The Senate has passed the Anglo-French Convention. M. Delcassé spoke of the happy | results of the entente with England and the advantages obtained in West Africa and Morocco, which compensate for the concessions made in Egypt and Newfoundland. (Havas.)

Paris, December 8. The Senate adopted without a division the Franco-Siamese Convention. M. Delcassé said that this treaty would assure to France a I preponderance in the Mekong Basin without moving a single soldier, or expending a centime.

Replying to the debate on the Anglo-French Convention, M. Delcassé said that his opponents had concentrated their criticisms on the question of Newfoundland, yet all that France had abandoned was the valueless fish-erring rights, and she had received in exchange important compensation elsewhere. This Convention was the result of a foreign policy based upon a plan which had been followed perseveringly for six years. In consequence of such plan, Spain and Italy had been conciliated and Great Britain no longer saw in France anything else but a tried worker, whom it would be difficult to replace in the field of peace and concord.
(Reuter.)
AUSTRIA AND TURKEY.
ULTIMATUM TO THE PORTE.
VIENNA, December 8. Austria has presented' an ultimatum to Turkey demanding the punishment of the Scutari officials who detained the mails. Unless this is done, the fleet will proceed to the Levant.
(Reuter.)
VIENNA, December 8. Turkey has agreed to secede to Austria's | demands. The incident is now regarded as closed.
(Reuter.)
ENGLAND'S TRADE.
BIG INCREASE IN EXPORTS.

LONDON, December 7. The exports during November show an increase of £3,000,000 and the imports of £2,000,000 compared with last year. During the 11 months tile increases are £6,500,000 for exports and £8,000,000 for imports. (R.)
AMERICAN COTTON.
MOVEMENT AMONG PLANTERS.
NEW ORLEANS, December 8. The plaiters in the cotton-growing States. have summoned mass meetings here, in order to devise some means of holding back the cotton.
(Reuter.)
PRINCE FAZIL AT MARSEILLES.
MARSEILLES, December 8. Prince Fazil has arrived. (Havas.)
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
THE CHRISTMAS TREE entertainment at Shepheard's Hotel will take place on the 25th inst. Invitations will be issued next week.
A POSTAL ERROR.-We regret to state that the issue of the Gazette of Saturday last for our Ramleh subscribers was despatched to Cairo through an error of the Post Office.
RABIES. There are an unusually large number of dog-bitten people at Kasr-el-Aini Hospital, Cairo, now. We hear 60 mentioned, though, of course, there is no proof that all the dogs were mad.

To BOOK LOVERS.--Mr. Marschner, the wellknown Cairo bookseller, has published an interesting list of new and second-hand books, chiefly Oriental and mostly from the library of the late Dr. C. Reinhardt, Consul at Bushir. Booklovers who have not received this list may have it post-free on application to Diemer's Bookstall, P. O. B. 311, Cairo.

HELOUAN.-In reference to a notice issued recently by the management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, residents and visitors may be reminded that the trains from Bab-elLouk station leave for Helouan at 9.10, 10.10, and 12.10, and not at 9.15, 10.15, and 12.10. Luncheon is served at. 1 p.m.

Suez Canal.-On the 5th inst. 10 vessels passed through the canal, 5 of which were British, 2 Austrian, 1 French, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch. On this day the receipts were frs. 276,329.34. On the 6th the number of vessels was 17, of which 13 were British, 1 Austrian, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Dutch, the receipts for the day being frs. 448,953.56. From the 1st to the 6th inst, the total receipts amounted to Irs. 2,256,088.50.

A VENDETTA AT Kafr ZAYAT.--The longstanding dispute between two well-known native families of Katr Zayat, the Pazari and the Rukubani, culminated some weeks ago in a street fight in which some of the former family were badly beaten. The Mulahiz of the police at Kafr Layat is accused by the Fazaris of having been very negligent in coming to their help and they have denounced that othcial to the Parquet. The matter is still under consideration by the Parquet, whose decision is awaited with great interest by the people of Katr Zayat.

"THE SPHINX." - This Cairo winter weekly journal has made its eleventh annual appear ance in an entirely new dress, which suits it | admirably. This first number contains some very interesting contributions which appeal to the resiuent and visitor alike, and a feature is made of financial news of a very informing character, to which a whole page is devoted. We believe that, as the season | advances, new features, more intimately connected with the movements and doings of our winter guests, will be added, and the attractiveness of the publication enhanced by half-tone illustrations of local and topical events. It is the aim of the editor to make his I journal reflect the non-political views of the
residents of the Capital, and he hopes to receive the co-operation of the latter in his task. The quality of the paper and printing leaves nothing to be desired.
THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive proceeded yesterday morning to Koubbeh Mosque, where he attended Bey. ram prayers.
The Beyram reception held at Abdeen Palace by his Highness was very largely attended.
To-morrow his Highness will open the horticultural exhibition at Ghezireh at 3 p.m.

CHRISTMAS DAY. We hear that the British professors employed in the Secondary Schools at Cairo will not, this year, get their Christmas Day free. Up to this year they have been, almost without exception, allowed a holiday on December 25, but this year, it is said, owing to the fact that the Arabic professors are unable to take the whole day's work through insufficiency in numbers, they will lose it.

We are, of course, aware that Christmas Day, like other European holidays, cannot, in a Moslem country, be observed to the same extent as in England, but we think it a pity that the authorities of the Ministry of Public Instruction cannot see their way to grant the concession to men,-many of whom are married and would naturally prefer to spend the day at home, who have done bard, and in some cases rather monotonous, work for some time past.

THE LATE MRS. WILSON. The funeral of the late Mrs. W. J. Wilson took place yesterday morning at the Old British Protestant Cemetery at Alexandria, and was attended by many of the older members of the British Colony. The body was brought from Cairo by the only son of the deceased lady, Mr. Louis Wilson, and the funeral service was conducted by the Rey. W. Wormell.

We would strongly recommend our readers to take particular notice of Mr. Heckscher's announcement and try their luck to win Al FORTUNE. (Advt.]
PRINCE'S VISIT TO EGYPT.
PRINCE LEOPOLD ARRIVING
ON TUESDAY.

Prince Leopold of Battenberg left Kensington Palace this day week for Egypt. His Highness travelled from Liverpool-street by the P. and O. boat train express to Tilbury, where he embarked on the steamship Arabia for Port Said. Princess Henry of Battenberg and Princess Ena were present at the station to bid him good-bye. Lord William Cecil travelled with the Prince to Tilbury. His Highness is expected at Port Said on Tuesday next and will proceed straight to Cairo. Lord Cecil has engaged a suite of rooms for his Highness at the Hotel d'Angleterre.

THE SINAI EXPEDITION. Mr. Monk Porch, the well-known Oxonian Egyptologist, who is on his way to explore the Sinai-tic peninsula in company with Pro essor Flinders Petrie, has arrived at Suez and will start from there by camel. It is well known that in ancient times large amounts of malachite were brought to Alexandria from Sinai, and it is hoped that a large business may be developed by reviving the export of this beautiful mineral.

Professor Flinders Petrie, whose age will not enable him to endure as much campaigning in the desert as he would like, will not undertake the search for flint instruments, which is a subject very dear to Mr. Monk Porch's heart. This search for malachite is a somewhat new departure for the professor, who has hitherto confined his attention more to antiquities than to commerce. The conjunction of these two able men should result in some very interesting researches, as Sinai is in a great measure an undiscovered country.
The old malachite mines are believed to have been located, but they have not been explored in recent times.
NUNGOVICH HOTELS. The election of the directors of the Nungovich Hotels Company has been postponed owing to the illness of Dr. Page-May, who is suffering from influenza.
ZIZINIA THEATRE.

LA GIOCONDA. Ponchielli's tuneful and favorite opera La Gioconda is so well-known, and so truly appreciated by the majority of the opera-going I public, that no surprise need be expressed at the audience which assembled last evening and taxed the seating accommodation of the house to its utmost limits. In spite of this, however, the performance failed to draw the house to any very great extent in the first or second acts, and there appeared to be an unaccountable coldness on each side of the footlights; even the moon beat & very hasty retreat. It was not until the closing of the third act, with its tragic scene and magnificent finale, that the audience were thoroughly roused, and all the artistes concerned were enthusiastically recalled again and again. As La Gioconda Sigpa. Amelia Pinto created a very favorable impression, both acting and singing with much artistic skill. Such a performance augurs well for the success of the several operas in which this lady is to appear. Signa. Margherita Julia was not altogether what we had anticipated as Laura Adorno. If the business so painfully evident occasionally, in the lower register, was due to cold, Signa. Julis was certainly very brave to have come forward. Her performance otherwise was exceedingly good. In the role of Enzo Grimaldi Sig. Francesco Bravi did not appear to be quite at ease, but whatever he lacked histrionically he certainly made up for vocally. Signor Bravi possesses a fine voice, which he has under good control, and although rather light for an opera such as Gioconda, he scored a distinct success. His rendering of the favorite "Cielo e mar" naturally brought forth the usual rounds of applause and consequent encore. As Alvise Badoero, Sig. Carlo Walter acted with dignity and sang, as he always does, with effect. Sig. Enrico Nani's performance was one much above the average, his singing and acting being of high artistic merit throughout the opera. Sig. Nani I will undoubtedly become a great favorite during the season. The very distressing character of La Cieca was ably sustained by Signa. Adele Ponzano. The two ballets danced during the evening were well executed, and the chorus was even better than usual, the invisible chorus in particular being exceedingly well rendered. Under the able bâton of Sig. Setti the orchestra was excellent, although in the third act and finale the eyeballs worked rather more than was pleasant for those sitting near.

ALHAMBRA THEATRE. There was a large house at the Alhambra | last night to welcome the new variety and ballet company which is now occupying the boards. The company is composed of very good elements, and an excellent show was presented. It would take up more space than we have at our disposal to enumerate the various "turns" on the programme, so many and varied are these, but the performances of "The Stewarts," equilibrists, Bepoil, French comique (who is, by the way, an old favorite here), Mlle Rosensteel, "diseuse," Mlle Mignon, balladist, and Mlle Ivon Hett, la poupée Parisienne, are worthy of special mention. We must candidly confess the ballet, Les Amours du Papillon, did not come up to our expectations, but this was probably due to the fact, announced, that no less than three of the fair participants were indisposed. We hope for better things in future.
LETTER TO THE EDITOR.

We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expresseded by our correspondent, but which, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain nasality limits our discussion. ICE SUPPLY OF ALEXANDRIA.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,--Having read the article on the above subject in your issue of yesterday's date, and being interested in the ice business, will you please allow us a brief space for a reply. Just previous to the commencement of the ice season--unfortunately for the public as well as the owners-the Société Anonymous Moulins d'Egypte's ice-works and flour-mills were almost entirely destroyed by fire, and out of four tree plants one only remained intact. The motor power having been destroyed by the fire, it was impossible to put these three ice plants again in working condition in time for the season ; consequently the above-named company were
only working one plant instead of four, which in reduced their output of ice to twelve tons re instead of forty-eight. The reason as to how the
fourth ice plant could be worked, is that this is I plant is completely isolated from the others, and

11 connected to separate motor-power. Had this of company been working all four ice plants, the mountain of ice in Alexandria would certainly as have been more than sufficient to meet the of public requirements. It is easy to see from
the above the reason why ice was high in m price, but the extra profit did not go into the
-pockets of the ice manufacturers, it was u reaped by the retail vendors, who took - advantage of an exceptional situation. In r. conclusion we may add that the three ice
plants of the Sooiété Anonyme des Moulins e d'Egypte have been again erected, and are in a position to be worked next season.
Thanking you for your space,
d'Egypte, ion to be worker spaces

Alexandria, December 8.
ABUSE OF MONOPOLY.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE,
Sir,--Frequent complaints are heard of dilatoriness on the part of the Telephone Co., | but action amounting to breach of contract is, - I hope, rare. My experience of a few days ago
is the following: | A customer in Ramleh, who is & subscriber to

the Telephone Co., endeavored to telephone to me relative to the repetition of an important order and also for some urgently-wanted medicine for his wife. To his astonishment communication was refused him, the employé informing him that, were he to do so, it would entail loss of his post. Imagining that & mistake had occurred, my client again endeavored to communicate with me, but met with refusal on three separate occasions. He then, at considerable loss of time and inconvenience, came to Alexandria and gave the order in person.
I take it for granted that the aim and Te object of the Telephone Company is to furnish

telephonic communication amongst subscribers, and with a view to information on the subject, and this particular case in question, I wrote to the Alexandria manager per registered letter and telegraphed to the general manager in Cairo requesting an explanation. This I probably being to them & matter of sueh frequent occurrence and of so little moment, neither of the aforesaid gentlemen thought fit to reply to my letter or telegram. I therefore crave the courtesy of your paper with a view to learning if other subscribers have been treated in a like manner.
Yours truly,
J. MacGREGOR. Sherif Pasha-st., Alexandria, Dec. 8.
Doo
SPORT AND PLAY.
CRICKET.
CAIRO.. ALEXANDRIA.

The Cairo Alexandria cricket match began yesterday in very uncertain and squally weather, which several times interrupted play. Alexandria began well, having 140 on the | board for 8 wickets before lunch, owing to some fine batting by H. B. Carver, the two
Maclarens, and Strange. After lunch, how however, the whole side got out for 199, Lockett i and Graves getting the wickets. Cairo began
badly in losing Lockett, who had hard luck in getting out off his pads, but thanks to Capt. Potter, who played a very steady innings and
was not out at the close of play, they did a better than their start promised. At the close el of play the score was 58 for 3 wickets, so that Alexandria may be said to hold a decided lead.

The Married v. Single cricket match on Saturday will not be played. A Rugby football match, Cairo e. The Provinces, will replace it, and will certainly be more seasonable, to judge from the weather that ushered in Beyram
FOOTBALL
E.T.C. v. BERKSHIRE Reor. The above teams mentioned Wednesday afternoon at the Sporting Club, and a very pleasant game ended in a win for the E.T.C. by 2 goals to 1.

A AQUILINA reporter
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.

Among the passengers who arrived at Port Said on Wednesday by the S.S. India were the Earl of Londesborough, Lord George Cbolmondeley, Lord Newton, Lord Redstockz Sir James Blyth, Sir Everard Doyle, Sir Robert Repner, M.P., and Lady Ropner and Sir Edward and Lady Stone.
H. E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Prime Minister, H.E. Mahmud Sidky Pasha, Governor of Alexandria, and Izzet Bey Choucry are spending the Beyram holidays at Mena
House.
Among others spending the holidays under the shadow of the Pyramids are Mrs. Du Boylay, Mr. Carter Wilson, Capt. Herbert, Miss Strachan, Miss B. M. Board, Miss Morrison, Dr Herbert W. Brown.
Many prominent Alexandrian’s arrived in Cairo for the Levée, among them Rear-Admiral Sir M. Blomfield, K.C.M.G., Michalla Pasha, Chitty Bey, and Mr. Macaulay.
Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield returned from Cairo yesterday evening.
Chitty Bey, Director General of Customs, will return from Cairo to-morrow morning.
Ahmed Pasha Fareed arrived yesterday evening from Cairo.

We deeply regret to announce the death of Mrs. Kyriacopoulo, the mother of our excellent confrère, Mr. Achilles Kyriacopoulo, proprietor and editor of the well-known Greek paper of Alexandria, Telegraphs. The funeral will take place this afternoon at 3 o'clock.

EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET. (FROM OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT.)

London, December. 4. The political situation since our last has not had much effect on Stock Exchange prices. A further delay has taken place in the negotiations foreshadowed in our previous article, owing to the fact that the war party in Russia had again got the upper hand, and have been trying to utilize the Indian frontier question to delay matters. One of the features in Egyptian stocks this week has been the renewed demand for Salt and Soda shares. The supply of shares on this market being almost exhausted, the natural result is that a further considerable advance in price has taken place, and there are at this moment large buying orders at 42s. which are still unsupplied. The price is an exaggerated one and offers a fine opportunity for profit-taking; at the same time those on your side who understand the position of affairs of this company will be able to draw their own conclusions. There has also been during the past week an active market in Egyptian Mining shares, notably Nile Valleys and United Africans. The former have been over 31. and the latter 2. There has been a set back from those prices during the last day or two, due in part to profit-taking, and it is also stated that the outside broker company which has had to meet its creditors had considerable interests in these shares.

It looks as if the check is only a temporary one; the market might take a fresh start at any moment. United Africans, which have fallen to 15 (their price to-day), look, cheap. It is said that they have, in cash and liquid assets, sufficient to pay about £2.10.0. per share. Bank shares are steady, Nationals 231, and Agricultural 104. Delta Light Railway Preference are & strong market at 15 and look like going better still, on their satisfactory report just issued. In general markets South Africans are easier-but with a good undertone, and a decided widening of business. Internationals are firm on the whole, and the American Market remains & wonderfully good one.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS. The Messengers Maritimes SS. Senegal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday at 3 p.m.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Conga will sail for Marseilles to-morrow at 4 p.m.
The Ellerman 8.S. Ararat sailed hence for Liverpool direct yesterday, with a general cargo, including 2,692 bales cotton.
The Ellerman S.S. Bulgarian sailed yesterday from Liverpool for Gibraltar, Malta, and Alexandria.
The Moss liner Seti sailed hence yesterday morning for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,124 bales cotton.
